questions.question: Q1. The number of presses shown in upsetting process module are:

explanations.a: Correct — In the upsetting process module, four different presses are demonstrated, each representing different force application conditions.
explanations.b: Incorrect — Only one press is not shown; multiple presses are demonstrated.
explanations.c: Incorrect — Three presses are less than the actual number shown.
explanations.d: Incorrect — Seven presses are not shown in the module.

questions.question: Q2. The L/D ratio used in interactive bench of simulation for upsetting process are:

explanations.a: Incorrect — These values are possible but not the ones used in the bench simulation.
explanations.b: Correct — The simulation commonly uses billet aspect ratios of 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 to study deformation patterns.
explanations.c: Incorrect — These are too large for typical upsetting simulation.
explanations.d: Incorrect — These ratios are used for tall cylindrical workpieces, not for upsetting simulation.

questions.question: Q3. Velocity of upper die in simulation for upsetting operation is:

explanations.a: Incorrect — These speeds are too low to represent complete deformation range.
explanations.b: Incorrect — Partially correct speeds but not the full range used.
explanations.c: Incorrect — These represent only higher strain rate conditions.
explanations.d: Correct — The simulation tests the effect of slow (1 mm/sec) & high (10 mm/sec) die speed on deformation.

questions.question: Q4. In upsetting operation which die moves:

explanations.a: Incorrect — The lower die is usually fixed in place.
explanations.b: Correct — In most forging and upsetting operations, the upper die moves downward to apply compression.
explanations.c: Incorrect — Both dies do not typically move in standard setups.
explanations.d: Incorrect — At least one die must move in upsetting.

questions.question: Q5. Which process involves increasing of the cross-sectional area by pressing or hammering in a direction parallel to the original ingot axis:

explanations.a: Incorrect — Peening improves surface finish and relieves stress, not used for cross-section increase.
explanations.b: Incorrect — Swaging reduces diameter using repeated blows.
explanations.c: Correct — Upsetting increases the diameter by shortening the height through axial compression.
explanations.d: Incorrect — Setting down is used for local reduction in thickness of a bar.
